G.L. c. 186..proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319C.proposition: This action is brought in the **Chelsea District Court**, which has subject matter jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19C and G.L. c. 185C, § 3.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This action is brought in the **Chelsea District Court**, which has subject matter jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19C and G.L. c. 185C, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the Property is located in Chelsea, Massachusetts, within the territorial jurisdiction of the Chelsea Division of the District Court Department. See G.L. c. 223, § 2; G.L. c. 239, § 2.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the Property is located in Chelsea, Massachusetts, within the territorial jurisdiction of the Chelsea Division of the District Court Department. See G.L. c. 223, § 2; G.L. c. 239, § 2.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides, in relevant part, that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment” of any residential premises by the occupant.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: In addition, the duty to maintain common areas in a condition reasonably safe and fit for occupancy is reinforced by the State Sanitary Code, promulgated under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Under the State Sanitary Code, landlords must maintain secure entry doors and door hardware and keep the premises in good repair. See 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.480 (locks and security) and 410.500 (maintenance of common areas).

105 C.M.R. 410.480.proposition: Under the State Sanitary Code, landlords must maintain secure entry doors and door hardware and keep the premises in good repair. See 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.480 (locks and security) and 410.500 (maintenance of common areas).

105 C.M.R. 410.500.proposition: Under the State Sanitary Code, landlords must maintain secure entry doors and door hardware and keep the premises in good repair. See 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.480 (locks and security) and 410.500 (maintenance of common areas).

105 C.M.R. 410.000.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of the statutory and common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment and an unlawful indirect interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Premises within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14, Massachusetts case law (including Blackett, Simon, Al-Ziab, Berman, and others), and related statutory and regulatory provisions, including 105 C.M.R. 410.000 and G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is **broadly construed** to protect tenants from serious interferences with the use and enjoyment of their leased premises caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716–18 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely treats the covenant of quiet enjoyment as covering serious interferences with tenants’ use of their premises that are the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts, omissions, or permissions, even without an intent to evict. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling and rejects a narrow malfeasance/nonfeasance distinction, thereby broadly construing the covenant to reach substantial noise and disturbance from a lounge the landlord introduced and could control.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did… they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that **failure to maintain safe and secure conditions** in common areas, such as locks and entryways, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.,  - Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–53 (1997) (affirming landlord liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 where conditions materially impaired tenant’s quiet enjoyment);  - Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–06 (1982) (recognizing that a landlord’s failure to remedy serious building problems affecting security and habitability can breach quiet enjoyment and support damages for emotional distress);  - Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–87 (1994) (discussing landlord’s duty to protect tenants from foreseeable criminal acts in common areas under certain circumstances).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The proposition is specifically about failure to maintain safe and secure common areas (locks, entryways, protection from criminal acts) as a breach of quiet enjoyment. Al‑Ziab does not concern security or common-area safety at all; it addresses whether a statutory lead paint violation, without proof of landlord fault, automatically constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that at least negligence is required. While it discusses the general standard for liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and cites other quiet enjoyment cases, it does not itself establish or apply a rule about security-related or common-area conditions, so it does not support the narrow proposition for which it is cited.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear…there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….”}

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that **failure to maintain safe and secure conditions** in common areas, such as locks and entryways, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.,  - Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–53 (1997) (affirming landlord liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 where conditions materially impaired tenant’s quiet enjoyment);  - Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–06 (1982) (recognizing that a landlord’s failure to remedy serious building problems affecting security and habitability can breach quiet enjoyment and support damages for emotional distress);  - Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–87 (1994) (discussing landlord’s duty to protect tenants from foreseeable criminal acts in common areas under certain circumstances).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The case squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” language and holds that a landlord’s violation of its duty to maintain sanitary, habitable conditions—here, repeated flooding with water and sewage in the tenant’s unit caused by failure to remedy building defects—constitutes an interference with quiet enjoyment. The court explains that § 14 is part of a regime ensuring “safe and sanitary housing” and that the landlord’s omission to correct these serious conditions, which impaired habitability and security of the premises, supports liability (including emotional distress damages) for interference with quiet enjoyment. Although the facts focus on flooding rather than locks or entryways, the reasoning clearly extends to serious building problems affecting safety and habitability in common or related areas.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing… The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’… signifi[es] the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute… Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–87 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that **failure to maintain safe and secure conditions** in common areas, such as locks and entryways, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.,  - Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–53 (1997) (affirming landlord liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 where conditions materially impaired tenant’s quiet enjoyment);  - Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–06 (1982) (recognizing that a landlord’s failure to remedy serious building problems affecting security and habitability can breach quiet enjoyment and support damages for emotional distress);  - Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–87 (1994) (discussing landlord’s duty to protect tenants from foreseeable criminal acts in common areas under certain circumstances).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to take reasonable measures within its control to address serious criminal activity in common areas can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court explains that if tenants effectively lose the use of common areas (streets, sidewalks, parking lots, recreational areas) due to crime, and the landlord has failed to take reasonable, relatively easy measures to remove unwelcome persons, that serious interference is actionable under G.L. c. 186, § 14. This directly supports the proposition that failure to maintain safe and secure conditions in common areas can breach quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment… We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908–09 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: A landlord’s persistent failure to respond to **known security defects** in common areas, where such defects allow repeated intrusions, thefts, or other serious disturbances, has been held to substantially interfere with tenants’ rights to quiet enjoyment. See Simon, 385 Mass. at 102–06; see also Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908–09 (1987) (recognizing significance of landlord inaction after notice).
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion never discusses quiet enjoyment, security defects in common areas, repeated intrusions/thefts, or landlord inaction after notice regarding such security problems. The only mention of security-related conditions is a bare listing of “inadequate door locks” among various sanitary code violations, and the court expressly treats most code violations as having minimal impact on use and enjoyment and focuses its legal analysis on utilities, security deposits, rent control, habitability, and c. 93A. The case therefore does not establish or recognize any rule about persistent failure to address known security defects substantially interfering with quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property.2 The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs. … The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–05 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: In addition, the duty to maintain common areas in a condition reasonably safe and fit for occupancy is reinforced by the State Sanitary Code, promulgated under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–05 (1979) (sanitary code violations may support claims relating to habitability and quiet enjoyment).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly links a landlord’s duties under the State Sanitary Code (promulgated under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L) to the modern warranty of habitability and rent remedies. It states that the Code imposes on landlords a duty to maintain habitable conditions and that noncompliance with the Code (e.g., failure to supply heat and hot water) constitutes a breach of the implied warranty of habitability, supporting tenant remedies such as rent abatement and reinforcing tenants’ rights to habitable, quiet enjoyment–type conditions.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “For example, the State Sanitary Code, adopted pursuant to authority granted in G. L. c. 111, § 5 (since amended, see G. L. c. 111, § 127A, for the current version), imposed on the landlord a duty to maintain an apartment in habitable condition, so the landlord could fairly expect and be expected to keep his rented premises habitable. Moreover, the Legislature had created tenant’s remedies for private enforcement of the Code, G. L. c. 111, §§ 127A-127H, and for self-help through rent withholding, G. L. c. 239, § 8A.”

DiMarzo v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 389 M.raw_text: DiMarzo v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 389 Mass. 85, 101–02 (1983)
DiMarzo v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 389 M.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, Plaintiff is entitled under G.L. c. 186, § 14 to recover **no less than three months’ rent ($4,500.00)**, plus costs, and reasonable attorney’s fees (if counsel is retained), regardless of whether her actual monetary loss is lower than three months’ rent. See DiMarzo v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 389 Mass. 85, 101–02 (1983) (recognizing mandatory nature of multiple damages under certain remedial statutes); see also Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400 (1982).
DiMarzo v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 389 M.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns mandatory statutory damages of at least three months’ rent under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for breach of quiet enjoyment, regardless of actual loss. DiMarzo is a Chapter 93A insurance bad-faith case about multiple damages under c. 93A, not about landlord-tenant law, c. 186, § 14, or a minimum three-months-rent measure of damages. While the opinion discusses that c. 93A allows multiple damages based on “actual damages,” it does not interpret c. 186, § 14 or hold that a tenant is entitled to not less than three months’ rent irrespective of actual monetary loss. The case is therefore inapposite to the specific proposition stated.
DiMarzo v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 389 M.relevant_excerpt: "Under c. 93A, the plaintiff is entitled to recover for all losses which were the foreseeable consequences of the defendant’s unfair or deceptive act or practice. International Fidelity Ins. Co. v. Wilson, 387 Mass. 841, 850 (1983). Clearly, the judgment and execution entered against MacDonald were the foreseeable consequences of American Mutual’s acts."

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400 (.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, Plaintiff is entitled under G.L. c. 186, § 14 to recover **no less than three months’ rent ($4,500.00)**, plus costs, and reasonable attorney’s fees (if counsel is retained), regardless of whether her actual monetary loss is lower than three months’ rent. See DiMarzo v. American Mut. Ins. Co., 389 Mass. 85, 101–02 (1983) (recognizing mandatory nature of multiple damages under certain remedial statutes); see also Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400 (1982).
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400 (.support_reasoning: Wolfberg does interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14 to allow a minimum recovery of three months’ rent (the ‘triple rent’ clause) for violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, regardless of the size of actual damages. However, the case is cited here for a different, more specific proposition: that a plaintiff is entitled to at least three months’ rent under § 14 even when she is also recovering multiple damages under another remedial statute (here, G.L. c. 93A). Wolfberg holds the opposite on this point, expressly disallowing recovery under § 14 where the tenant has already recovered more than both actual damages and three months’ rent under c. 93A based on the same facts, to avoid duplicative recovery.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400 (.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, as amended by St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, allows tenants to recover ‘actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater,’ for violation of that statute. … We have held recently that duplicative recovery of actual damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14, and other common law and statutory claims will not be permitted… We now hold that, where a tenant has been awarded in excess of both three months’ rent and actual damages under G. L. c. 93A on claims based upon the same set of facts as in a concurrent claim for damages for violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, the recovery of damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14, would be duplicative and, therefore, will not be allowed.”
